edge.models

Class Settings

  • java.lang.Object
    • edge.models.BaseModel
      • edge.models.Settings

  • @Entity
public class Settings
extends BaseModel
    This JPA model represents a Windows-Registry-Like interface for dealing with various configurations for the user.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      private java.lang.Integer id 
      private java.lang.String keyName 
      private java.lang.String stringValue 
      private User user 

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Settings()
      A basic constructor for the settings class.
      Settings(User user, java.lang.String key, java.lang.String defaultValue)
      Constructs a new Settings object with the user, key and default value already present.

      Modifier and Type Method and Description

      gets the ID of the current settings object
      java.lang.String getKeyName()
      gets the keyName of the setting it has to be keyName because of the way hibernate's mapping works.

      gets the value of the setting as string.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Settings

        public Settings()
        A basic constructor for the settings class.

      • Settings

        public Settings(User user,
                java.lang.String key,
                java.lang.String defaultValue)
        Constructs a new Settings object with the user, key and default value already present. You can quickly create a setting the for active user for example: Settings s = Settings(EdgeSession.getActiveUser(), "yourSetting", "yourInitialValue") and save it afterwards with ease: Database.saveAndCommit(s);
        Parameters:
        user - a user object
        key - the key of the setting as a string
        defaultValue -

    • Method Detail

      • getId

        public java.lang.Integer getId()
        gets the ID of the current settings object
        Returns:
        the ID as an integer TODO: maybe use long for IDs?

      • setId

        public void setId(java.lang.Integer id)
        sets the ID of the current settings object be aware of the fact that IDs must be unique! if not, Hibernate will UPDATE a different setting instead.
        Parameters:
        id - the ID as an integer

      • getKeyName

        public java.lang.String getKeyName()
        gets the keyName of the setting it has to be keyName because of the way hibernate's mapping works.
        Returns:
        a string representing the key of the setting

      • setKeyName

        public void setKeyName(java.lang.String keyName)
        sets the keyName of the setting
        Parameters:
        keyName - a string representing the key (should be unique for the user to avoid issues when dealing with settings

      • getStringValue

        public java.lang.String getStringValue()
        gets the value of the setting as string. there is no class supported other than string because we decided to keep the parsing to the external classes. we can't really predict the type of the setting without offering a huge amount of columns (which would go against the third normal form)
        Returns:
        the value of the setting as string

      • setStringValue

        public void setStringValue(java.lang.String stringValue)
        sets the value of the setting
        Parameters:
        stringValue - a string value for the setting (key => value)

      • getUser

        public User getUser()
        return the user which belongs to the setting
        Returns:
        any user object

      • setUser

        public void setUser(User user)
        sets the user for the specific setting
        Parameters:
        user - any user object
